Posts.Content: Can certainly understand your frustration but if you could fill in a few other details it might make his hesitancy more easy to understand. What is his PSA, the doubling time, what is his age, how is his health, what is his family history besides his brother, does he have other co-morbities? A biopsy is the sensible first step for the vast majority of men suspected of having PCa but not for all, for a small number the answer to those questions is critical because for a small minority of men a biopsy is not trivial and serious even life threatening complications may insue and other tests including a 3T Mri may be more appropriate given the answer to those questions...remember treatment for suspected or confirmed PCA is almost never an emergency... IMO what you really need to do is to have a heart to heart with him and understand his concerns so that both of you go forward together. Good luck

Posts.Title: Husband wants second PSA test~

Posts.Content: Sorry to see that you have to be here looking for advice, but as mentioned by other posters only you and your husband can decide what's the best treatment option. Many here often refer to how you are "wired" in making treatment choices, for some for some prolonging life at any cost is worth it for others quality of life is most important. The fact that you are here asking, indicates to me at least, that as a couple you are probably "wired" to forego dubious life prolonging treatment and instead concentrate on maximizing the quality of the remaining time you have together. You might seek another opinion but the numbers you have presented pretty much speak for themselves. In my case, I am going to succumb to something other than PCa in the next few years and I have chosen to maximize the quality of life both for myself and my family. I must say that once I made that decision, and with the support of my family I find this is the best time of my life and I wake up each morning savoring the time we have together and go to sleep each night satisfied I had lived one more of our days together to its fullest. But I and my family are "wired" that way. I would suggest both of you to do some soul searching to come up what is the best course for you. There is no right or wrong answer only the best one for you.

Posts.Title: Husband wants second PSA test~

Posts.Content: I have been on 5mg/day of finasteride for about a year and a half. It dropped my PSA from 11.18 to 4.00 over the course of about a year. There is some debate about how much to multiply the finasteride PSA value to approximate pre drug levels, some say 2x others say 2.3x after a few years on the drug. The fact is that no one knows for sure but most research shows the drop should be large (40-70%) in the absence of clinically significant cancer. It sounds to me what your urologist is proposing is what is called the "Finasteride Challenge". That is your PSA should drop by at least 50% within 3-6 months after taking the drug, if the PSA does not drop by at least half during that time or if it stays the same or even increases then there is a likelihood that clinically significant cancer may be present. I tend to look at it as a way to filter the noise out of the PSA values. Additionally, there are some studies out there that indicate finasteride increases the chance of a positive biopsy, probably due to the fact that it will decrease the size of the prostate thus increasing the chance they will hit something. I have not had any side effects to speak of from taking the drug but some men experience very troubling side effects including growing man boobs, loss of libeto, ED etc., that at least in a few men may continue even after the use of the drug is stopped. If it is prescribed I'd want a MD with a lot of experience in its use and who has a through understanding of the potential side effects and most importantly has communicated that information to you so you know what to look out for....

If it is prescribed I'd want a MD with a lot of experience in its use and who has a through understanding of the potential side effects and most importantly has communicated that information to you so you know what to look out for....

Posts.Title: Doc prescribed Finasteride (Proscar) today - questions...

Posts.Content: I have been on 5mg/day of finasteride for about a year and a half. It dropped my PSA from 11.18 to 4.00 over the course of about a year. There is some debate about how much to multiply the finasteride PSA value to approximate pre drug levels, some say 2x others say 2.3x after a few years on the drug. The fact is that no one knows for sure but most research shows the drop should be large (40-70%) in the absence of clinically significant cancer. It sounds to me what your urologist is proposing is what is called the "Finasteride Challenge". That is your PSA should drop by at least 50% within 3-6 months after taking the drug, if the PSA does not drop by at least half during that time or if it stays the same or even increases then there is a likelihood that clinically significant cancer may be present. I tend to look at it as a way to filter the noise out of the PSA values. Additionally, there are some studies out there that indicate finasteride increases the chance of a positive biopsy, probably due to the fact that it will decrease the size of the prostate thus increasing the chance they will hit something. I have not had any side effects to speak of from taking the drug but some men experience very troubling side effects including growing man boobs, loss of libeto, ED etc., that at least in a few men may continue even after the use of the drug is stopped. If it is prescribed I'd want a MD with a lot of experience in its use and who has a through understanding of the potential side effects and most importantly has communicated that information to you so you know what to look out for....

Posts.Content: The MRI grade is a system of scoring that radiologists use called PIRADS which goes from a 1, which means cancer is unlikely to be present to a 5 which means cancer is probably present. A PIRADS score of 3, means Equivocal...which is basically is saying maybe yes or maybe no. The lesion can be caused by many things other than cancer, the biopsy will sample the lesion to find out what is there. As noted he is on the young side for PCa and the fluctuating PSA is usually a sign of BPH or prostitis rather than cancer.

Posts.Content: I am older than you but I also have a number of co-morbidities that are more likely to kill me than prostate cancer. One of the risks of a biopsy is an infection spreading to the bloodstream, as a diabetic your chances of this happening are higher than most undergoing the procedure. Should blood sepsis develop and because of your heart condition you could potentially face a life threating cardiac event. Personally, I'd put the biopsy off for six months and pursue a course of treatment for your present symptoms.

Posts.Content: Agree with Dog, if you have an AO rating, you are covered 100% as long as you stay in the VA system, including Veterans Choice and doing like he is doing it is the way to go. The caution I have is that should you receive PCa care that is billed to Medicare, you are responsible for the 20% copay unless you have a supplemental or advantage plan. The VA will not pick up that 20%.....

Posts.Title: VA vs University Medical

Posts.Content: Brownie Can certainly understand your wanting to get started as soon as possible. A drop in the PSA due to treatment won't affect your rating. You will be responsible for the Medicare Advantage copay's at the University, their financial department can give you an estimate of how much it will be depending on the type of Advantage plan you have. It could be expensive depending on your particular plan and how much you you have used Medicare so far this year. It should not be a problem having your PCP write a script for the ADT. If the ADT is on the VA formulary you can continue with that. Generally the VA formulary is more extensive than what is offered by the advantage plans so its possible you won't have to change. As Dog mentioned getting a referral to Oncology by your PCP should not be a problem. If your VA doesn't have a oncology department that's when Veterans Choice comes in. In the unlikely event your pcp won't refer you then get the Veterans Advocate at your facility involved. As for the ED issues your pcp or oncologist can prescribe something to deal with that. Dog can probably give you more info on the additional rating. One other thing you might want to consider. Since you are already enrolled you can switch between Medicare Advantage plans between October 15th and December 7th for coverage beginning January 1st. Depending on what area of the country you are in you might be able to find a more cost effective plan to fit your needs going forward. I've been in the VHC system for almost longer than I can remember and have received excellent care but some guys don't want to deal with it for anything more than their prescriptions and having the best Advantage plan possible may work for them. Good luck

Posts.Title: VA vs University Medical

Posts.Content: If the expense is a concern I'd definitely go with the VA. My PCP like most in the VA system is very good at accommodating my treatment choices. Also although it can take forever to get an appointment if something is urgent they have gotten me an appointment in a day or two. I just noticed you are on medicare. You need to be aware that medicare and VHC are totally separate and do not work together. If you want the VA to cover it you need to have them make the diagnosis and set up a treatment plan. Its ok for them to go off what your medicare providers found but you need to be careful how your treatment would be billed by your medicare providers. If its not done right you could end up with a bill from either medicare or the VA. Its complicated, PM if you have more specific questions.

Posts.Content: There are lots of statistics out there that show that men who are African or have an African ancestry are more likely to be diagnosed with PCa. At the same time there are plenty of statistics that show those of Northern European ancestry for example are more likely to be diagnosed with a genitic disorder such as hemochromatosis, than Africans, that untreated, will kill them far quicker than PCa or for that matter and many other cancers. Although there are many correlations between ethnicity and susceptibility to a particular cancer what is unknown is whether a particular race predisposes one to PCa or any other cancer. Cancer has been around for millions of years, its a safe bet that PCa as with all cancers is not politically correct.....but one having a particular racial background would be wise to heed the statistics and act in their best interests...

Posts.Content: Hi I've been taking Finasteride for a little more than a year and during that time it reduced the PSA number from 11.18 to 4.0. It looks like Finasteride dropped your PSA by about two thirds similar to my experience with the drug. I'm certainly no expert and everyone is different but my intuition would be that it very well could take at least as long to go up as it did to down.... so taking a year or two after long term use to come to a true value might be a reasonable guess. I have neurological issues, recent testing shows my bladder has stopped working and I have to self catheterize 4-6 times a day. I would think your URO would want to do a cystocopy and urodynamic testing to zero in on the cause of your urinary symptoms. Given your brother's history you certainly want to investigate the PSA but dont stop there, get to the bottom of what is causing your LUTS.

Posts.Content: I self catheterize 4-6 times a day which of course opens me up to the possibility of recurrent UTI's but I seldom get one. I trust the Doc at the urgent care gave you an antibiotic to take care of the present infection but once the antibiotics are done I'd recommend you practice prevention until you are fully continent. What I do for prevention is to keep my urine acidic. I take a 50-100 mg Vitamin C a day which works, I also took a 4200 mg Cranberry cap a day which also worked. But don't get carried away with the Vitamin C ...100 a day is plenty, taking a 1000 or more a day causes kidney stones in some...

Posts.Title: How Long Until Finasteride No Longer Affects PSA?

Posts.Content: Although only a biopsy can diagnose prostate cancer the 3T MRI is becoming an good tool to determine who may need a biopsy and locating areas of suspicion for a later targeted biopsy.. The MRI is scored with the PIRADS system that goes from 1-5 as follows: •PI-RADS 1: very low (clinically significant cancer is highly unlikely to be present) •PI-RADS 2: low (clinically significant cancer is unlikely to be present) •PI-RADS 3: intermediate (the presence of clinically significant cancer is equivocal) •PI-RADS 4: high (clinically significant cancer is likely to be present) •PI-RADS 5: very high (clinically significant cancer is highly likely to be present) It sounds like you are a PIRADS 2. Most urologists would defer doing a biopsy at this time based on your score. Also a fluctuating PSA may indicate BPH or prostitis rather than PCa, which usually shows a steady increase. You want to ask the urologist his reasoning for the biopsy with the low PIRADS score....it could be that he needs to pay his kids fall tuition...

Posts.Content: What prompted my curiosity is my buddy with kidney cancer. We are both Vietnam/Vietnam era vets and have been in the VA healthcare system for years. I drive 500 miles to a large VA medical center affiliated with a well known medical school to get my care. He gets his care at a rural VA hospital up here or a local VA clinic. I have been taking him in for his visits and have noted that for him and a lot of vets I run into the cost of treatment is the driving factor in their treatment decisions. He needed a PET scan to see how far the cancer had spread, the VA hospital up here doesn't have a scanner so he needed to go locally to one of the few hospitals in the state that had a scanner. It took a couple of months for the VA to do the paperwork before he could get in for the scan and apparently its going to take a few weeks more before the results will work the way through the system and get to his provider. I've suggested that he sign up for medicare during the general enrollment period starting in January and coverage would start in July, with his diagnosis it makes sense to me to have more options for treatment in the civilian system. Unfortunately, he is dependent on SS and a small VA pension and simply can't afford the medicare premium and makes a bit to much to qualify for premium assistance from the State. My conversations with other vets leads me to believe believe his situation is not unique. My sense is that most seeking advice on the various forums have the resources to follow up with the treatment suggestions and folks like my buddy fall through the cracks...

Posts.Content: Steve I self catheterize but I'm not an expert.... 1. A duet catheter is a Foley catheter with 2 balloons it is marketed by Poiesis under the brand name Duette its still a Foley catheter, I suspect your urologist thinks all Foley catheters whether with one or two balloons are the same. 2. DO NOT try to remove it on your own. You will seriously damage your bladder and cause more problems than you all ready have. If you are determined to remove it go to your nearest ER immediately and have them do it Good luck Joe

Posts.Title: I wonder if anyone has any comments on either of two points

Posts.Content: I admit that I probably consider and give credence to the opinions of those posting here but I do wonder if we are in the same economic universe... The stock advice to a new guy posting is to get the best Doc's, have mpMRI's, genomic testing, etc..in other words cost is no object when your life is at stake... But how about those of limited means? those with dependents who want to leave their family a few bucks? With my relentless mental decline, I find that I wish I PCa was my only problem, but I got to thinking if the other commodities were not there and if I could I afford the best treatment would I want to?

Posts.Title: Does your economic status influence your treatment choice..

Posts.Content: I have not shared the details of my status outside of the anonymous internet with anyone but one or two close friends However, one of those close friends for the last 61 years has just been diagnosed with kidney cancer that has apparently metastasized. He has chosen to wait 6 months to make a decision on any /or if any form of treatment he may pursue ....but is likely to do nothing. I think he has been heavily influenced by the non treatment choices I have made which causes me a bit of reflection...and frankly concern. What works for one individual does not work for another even it they are your best buddy.. So I guess my broader ponderance is how much of your personal health history should one share with others in your daily life as opposed to an annonymous forum...given the chance those that know you rather than an internet name may follow a path that is fine for you but bad for them...

Posts.Title: Thinking of passing on salvage radiation.

Posts.Content: Hi TB I don't know about the costs of the particular institution, but remember that it would be 20% or 40% of the Medicare allowable costs. For example, say the hospital charges $100,000 but medicare only allows $30,000. The maximum your father would be responsible for at 20% would be $6000 not $20,000 or and at 40% $12,000 not $40,000. You should be able to get an estimate from the institution before beginning treatment. But remember you need estimates from the hospital, surgeons, radiologists, anesthesiologists everybody and you also need to make sure they accept Medicare. From your description it sounds like your Dad has Medicare Part C... a Medicare Advantage Plan. The open enrollment period is coming up around October 15th for changes starting January 1, 2018. It might be wise to shop around for a plan that will meet his needs better that his present plan during that period. The monthly premium will likely be higher than what he is paying now but with the costs he is facing it may be worth it. He is not eligible for a supplemental (the F,N,A etc plans), he needed to sign up within 6 months of when he first became eligible for medicare which for most people is age 65 unless he was covered by private insurance after age 65.

My advice would be to listen to your urologist and have another...

Posts.Content: Most here have chosen curative treatment/surgery because they are not "wired" for AS or WW. Their treatment has worked for them and understandably they simply cannot conceive of why anyone would not follow their treatment choices. However, in the real world outside of a forum, many factors weigh into ones treatment choices. It seems both you and your physician are satisfied with the course of your treatment. That is the only factor that has any importance, you have to do what is right for you.

Posts.Title: mixed results on 3rd biopsy

Posts.Content: I'm sorry you have to here. Sometimes the doctors are saying a lot by not saying anything. As hard as it is to accept no one gets out of this life alive and at a certain point as hard as it is to do, you and/or your husband may want to start asking the questions nobody wants to ask. There is no right or wrong way to go about it, just the way that works for both of you. As a first step you might ask your doctor if palliative care would be appropriate at this point. There are many resources out there available to help but unfortunately for most docs and patients the questions come to late to take full advantage of what might be most helpful for both of you. Good luck and bless you and your husband..

Posts.Title: Is it time to worry?

Posts.Content: It seems to me that numbers do not lie, for most men the cost of false positive PSA testing and the resulting cost of over treatment of indolent cancers that would have never been an issue, is a waste of limited health care dollars, and yes there is only a limited number of dollars to go around, irregardless how highly one may value their own life. Everyone here who has benefited from early detection by a routine PSA obviously would want everyone else to have the same benefit, but what is lost in this argument is that those of you in this group are a minority of PCa patients as hard as that may be to accept based on your personal experience. The bottom line is this, every dollar spent on the over diagnosis and over treatment of indolent prostrate cancers that never would have threated one's health is a dollar taken away from everyone else with medical conditions that could have actually benefited from those medical dollars.

Posts.Title: US Recommendations Against PSA Test Taken to Heart by PCPs

Posts.Content: Can't comment on post RALP retention but I have been self catheterizing for close to two years and I can say that it definitely gets easier with time should he find it necessary to continue for awhile. The biggest challenge for most is getting over the mental barrier. If it has not cleared up in a month or two he should have a cytoscopy and a procedure called urodynamic testing. The testing will tell what the problem is and the cystocopy gives a close up look at the urethra and bladder. The three most common causes of urinary retention are urethral obstruction, malfunction of the detussor muscle in the bladder and nerve damage. Urethral obstruction can be fixed, problems with the detussor can usually be rehabilitated with time, nerve damage, which I have, is permanent. If it dosen't get better in a few months I'd caution him not to have any procedure until the cytoscopy and urodynamic testing are done. Most uro's have little experience with chronic urinary retention and their tendency is to keep trying things until they stumble on something that works....an academic medical center is the place to go if it persists.

Posts.Title: Non pc post, kind of...

Posts.Content: I've been in the VA system for longer than I can almost remember I've gotten excellant care but sometimes you need to be very proactive on your own behalf to get anything done. I would suggest you get a second opinion from a MO that your insurance will cover. As long as you have private insurance and VAHC there is no reason to limit yourself to the VA. Take the second opinion back to the VA and request to be seen by another MO. If you meet any resistance contact the Veteran Advocate's office at the facility every hospital has one. What many guys do is get their Rx from their civilian MD's and then have their VA primary care provider or specialist rewrite the Rx so that the VA can fill it. Most don't have any problem doing this and again if you do contact the VA advocates office..in the VA the squeekey wheel definitely gets the grease. If you have any questions about your specific facility shoot me a PM

Posts.Title: Psa rising hormone therapy not working very concerned

Posts.Content: Thanks to everyone for the words of encouragement. I guess I was not clear in my original post. I have been diagnosed with dementia which is progressive and ultimately fatal. It is expected I will be mentally incapacitated, unaware of my surroundings and family, and unable to care for myself within 10 years, which in my point of view is the same as being dead within 10 years. I have read that treatment is often not initiated if the patient has a comorbidity that gives him a less than 10 year life span. I am in this boat from my perspective. So I guess I'm interested in experiences from those who have limited lifespans from other causes who have PCa or have suspected PCa. I realize a prostrate biopsy has a low risk of complications but in my present situation does taking any risk make sense? I think not.
Posts.Title: Biopsy/Treatment if in early stages of Dementia

Posts.Content: I'm 65 male, PSA has been around 7-8 for past few years but went to 10 between March and May. I refused biopsy when it was 8 saying if it ever got to 10 I'd get one. I've been scheduled for one in a few weeks. I have been diagnosed with early stage dementia caused primarily by a TBI, additionally I had genetic testing within the last year for iron overload and was found to have a genetic mutation the greatly increases the probability that I will get Parkinson's, ALS or Alzheimer's...the old brain is not in the best of shape. I have young wife and boy and girl 9 & 10 and therefore the quality of life while I still have the mental capacity to enjoy it is far more important to me than the quantity...I'd rather be dead than go on for years with the brain of a one year old and put my family through that. I've decided to monitor my mental status but not have biopsies or treatment for the prostrate (or any other medical condition that might come up). I would be curious if anyone else has been a similar situation and how they handled it.

Posts.Content: Hi Tinkerbell I've been following your story and posted a few times along the way. I know you are trying to do what is best for your dad because you love him so. If I could make a gentle observation that you should feel free to disregard. From your first posts it seemed your 69 year old father had a number of medical issues in addition to the PCa diagnosis, from your description of the consults it may be that you (and him?) have decided on the treatment you want him to have. The physician who has seen your dad and knows his medical history the best and is not focused on "cure" is the one you like the least.....Aggressive treatment in a 69 year old with the co-morbidities you described in your earlier posts does not always end well. Every one has to make their own treatment choices, again trying not to be critical, I'd suggest you sit down and have a heart to heart with your dad to find out what HE wants and not what he thinks you want for him. I have a young wife and daughter and know how difficult it can be to do whats best ultimately for them when dealing with what they want for me now. There are many options available and reading into your care and concern I think you need to go the extra mile for both of you in assuring he makes the right choice for him no matter how hard that may be for you.... Good luck and God Bless

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer and dropping PSA?

Posts.Content: "However, this must be pointed out that what MD Anderson state is the NORM," You are correct, the top treatment centers across the board seem to have a similar policy. The interesting thing to me is that this information has not filtered into the forums dealing with prostate cancer. I've been sampling the various forums out there and it seems all have either a subtle or a very pronounced bias toward a particular treatment selection. I guess what I'm saying is that it's unfortunate that it is seemingly impossible for anyone with low risk disease (or even to get a accurate definition of low risk disease) or with co-morbidities to get an unbiased and straight forward assessment of their options regardless of age. The MD's most of us see are peddling their trade, the forums one might visit are frequented by those with positive/negative outcomes and they are naturally arguing for/against a particular treatment.

Posts.Title: Life expectancy for advanced prostate cancer in an 81 year old man with an 8 Gl score

Posts.Content: Well as long as you asked for pro and con I'll jump in. All surgery has inherent risks and most studies show it takes at least 10 years for the risks of prostrate surgery to out weigh the benefit. AS means just that, your are actively engaged in your treatment and should something change you can address it. At my age and with the other problems I have I pretty much won't add to them by adding any more risk, for me QOL now is my priority. Because your MD's are recommending AS I'd consider sitting down and having a frank discussion with them. If they are recommending AS solely based on your age I'd be skeptical but if their recommendation is based on your age and other aspects of your health history (co-morbidities) I'd want to know. Of course what to do is a decision only you can make..

Posts.Content: I had cataract surgery back in December. The alpha blockers also increase the risk of Interoperative Floppy Iris Syndrome (IFIS), so if Cataract Surgery is in your future and you have BPH your urologist might consider the 5 alpha reductase inhibitors (finesteride, dutesteride) instead. Of course the 5 reductase inhibitors reduce the PSA values which can make tracking PCa more difficult..everything is a trade off.. In any case if you are on Flomax and are undergoing cataract surgery make sure the surgeon is aware of that fact..

Posts.Content: Sorry you have to be here. Reading a bit between the lines here, but your statement that you can lead a horse..and the fact he skipped last years PSA makes me wonder if both of you are on the same page. You, of course, want your Dad to pursue every treatment option open to him. However, as hard as it may be for you to accept, the ultimate treatment choices are up to him. Sit down, have a heart to heart talk, and truly understand what his wishes are. Obviously, you want to be as close as possible to your Dad at this point of his life and the only way to do that is to provide information but realize the ultimate treatment decisions are his and his alone....

Posts.Title: 65 Years Old Male PSA 12, DRE feels hardness on the right side, waiting for biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Bill The MD's treating your MS should be interacting with the MD's treating your PCa to determine the best course forward. As you are probably aware MS is an autoimmune disease and radiation can have a profound effect on the immune system. I suspect the concern is not SE's but the possibility that radiation could irreparably damage your immune system with potentially dire consequences. If I recall correctly there are at least 5 types of MS and only the physicians treating your MS would be knowledgeable enough of your particular case to guide the Doc's treating your PCa going forward. I also have neurological concerns and have found that it is impossible to isolate and treat one aliment without that treatment having an effect on the rest of my body. You are one of those patients with a "complex" medical history and to be treated effectively all of the MD's treating you need to be on board with a treatment plan that takes all of your conditions into account. I've found that having one MD that is aware of your entire medical situation who can advise you and who can direct your care by coordinating with all the specialists involved works best. You can't do it on your own. Good luck...

Posts.Content: Hi I've been taking 5mg/day of Finasteride since last October. After about 3 months it dropped the PSA from 11 to 5 and prostate had shrunk to about 35 cm. My docs told me the response did not rule out PCa but it made it less likely that it is aggressive. They become concerned when the PSA drops less than 50% or even rises while taking it, they referred to it as the "Finasteride challenge". I'm doing a 3T MRI next week Some guys have sexual side effects such as ED from the drug but for me its has been side effect free. As always everyone is different ..good luck to you and your hubby..

Posts.Title: Husband has PSA 14. Please need advice about using Finasteride.

Posts.Content: I think how one is wired is actually the most important factor in one's choice of treatment. For the majority here watchful waiting or active surveillance are not even considered as treatment for PCa. I have posted in previous threads my PSA values over the last 10 years but in short it's increased from around 3 to about 9 or 10 today, my primary care provider has had me repeatedly sign off on the fact that I most assuredly have PCa, that they have advised me of that fact, and I have refused treatment. Due to the other risk factors in my particular case, this course makes the most sense to me, and therefore I have chosen to simply live with it, because that's the way I'm wired. I know others in my same situation would pursue more aggressive treatment. As I look back over the last 10 years, in my particular case, I'm sure choosing aggressive treatment would have always made me wonder what would have happened if I had done nothing. I think what it comes down to is to trust your gut. There is no right or wrong course of treatment only the best one for you...

Posts.Title: My dad has been diagnosed with prostate cancer just recently

Posts.Content: Hello sorry you have to be here. A single PSA in the 100's while certainly concerning does not necessarily indicate PCa. BPH or Prostitus could be a cause of the elevated PSA. The biopsy on Thursday will help get that issue sorted out. As far as an interim solution to resolve the pee issue, its possible the Flomax would begin working well enough by the end of July for your father to void naturally, if not he could use a catheter. With a catheter there are three options. A Foley catheter with the which is what he got at the ER, having the bag attached makes it less than ideal for travel but its possible. The second is a suprapubic catheter which involves inserting a catheter directly into the bladder through an incision in the lower abdomen above the pubic bone. They have a valve and a detachable bag which would make travel easier. The third option is self catherization or CIC (Clean Intermitant Catherization) the system I use and what people with spinal chord injuries use. This involves inserting a catheter into the urethra and emptying the bladder when needed. This works really well for people who can do it. I PM'd you a link to more information on CIC. Good luck.

Posts.Content: I've been in the VA system for many years and am very happy with the care I have received. You can get care at any VA hospital in the country provided you are willing to wait for an appointment and travel on your own dime. I live quite a distance from the nearest VA hospital so they often schedule me with local MD's. But for the big things I go to the nearest big city VA hospital affiliated with a medical school. If I was concerned and in your shoes I would have your PCP refer you to the VA hospital in Philly or wherever you might find a experienced surgeon affiliated with an academic center.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed, 4+3 with PNI

Posts.Content: In my case I have never had a prostate biopsy and I don't intent to ever have one. But I have other co-morbidities that will likely kill me or dementia will set in within 10 years so the risk/benefit equation doesn't work for me. So you might consider the other health issues you may have in making your decision Another thing you might consider is what would your treatment choices be should it come back positive. Are you the type of individual who would want curative treatment immediately regardless of Gleason score or are you the type of individual who would be comfortable pursuing watchful waiting or active surveillance. The risks of complications in a prostate biopsy are quite low but they do happen, you know your body best. Some guys never get sick and sail through every medical procedure others catch everything that is going around and consistently react badly to any medical procedure. Only you know where you fall on that spectrum and only you know how you would feel should you be one of the few that does have a serious complication, are you the type that would be kicking yourself forever for taking the risk or would you just blow it off. It seems to me the advice to pursue noninvasive procedures first is sound given your reluctance, but no one can decide what is best for you but you. I tend to trust my gut...

Only you know where you fall on that spectrum and only you know how you would feel should you be one of the few that does have a serious complication, are you the type that would be kicking yourself forever for taking the risk or would you just blow it off. It seems to me the advice to pursue noninvasive procedures first is sound given your reluctance, but no one can decide what is best for you but you. I tend to trust my gut...
